title: The 10 Elements of Agroecology: Enabling transitions to sustainable agriculture and food systems

tasks.task: Understand the urgent need for global transition to sustainable agriculture.
subtasks: Recognize current food system failures in meeting sustainable development indicators.
Acknowledge the imperative for farming systems that ensure food security while reversing environmental degradation and adapting to climate change.
Comprehend the definition of agroecology as a shift towards custom-made, biologically diverse production systems.
Appreciate the interconnectedness of ecological, social, economic, and nutritional components in agroecology.
Understand the role of diversity in enhancing ecological functions such as pollination, pest control, and soil health.
Learn about the importance of co-creation and sharing of knowledge in designing diversified agricultural systems.

tasks.task: Understand the concept of agricultural diversification.
subtasks: Define diversification in agriculture and its importance in generating multiple benefits to stakeholders.
Recognize how diversification can help in minimizing trade-offs and enhancing resource use efficiency.
Understand the practice of recycling organic residues to improve soil health and reduce environmental impacts.

tasks.task: Assess the social dimensions of agricultural sustainability.
subtasks: Acknowledge the need for dignified, equitable, and inclusive rural livelihoods in sustainable agriculture.
Recognize the role of human and social values in building social capital and collective action.

tasks.task: Recognize the role of culture and food traditions in agroecology.
subtasks: Understand how agroecology supports diversified diets for food and nutrition security.
Recognize the importance of harmonizing traditional and modern food habits for sustainable production and consumption.

tasks.task: Recognize the importance of responsible governance and innovation in agroecology transitions.
subtasks: Comprehend the need for transparent, accountable, and inclusive governance mechanisms.
Understand the role of circular and solidarity economies in connecting producers and consumers.
Recognize the significance of bottom-up approaches in developing context-specific solutions.

tasks.task: Understand the 10 elements of the agroecology framework.
subtasks: Acknowledge the interlinkage and interdependency of the 10 elements.
Recognize the key components and emergent properties described in the agroecology framework.

tasks.task: Recognize the importance of partnership and innovation in agricultural transitions.
subtasks: Understand the role of research and producer collaboration in driving global transformative change.
Comprehend the necessity for sharing knowledge based on scientific evidence and field experience.

tasks.task: Gain information on further resources for agroecology knowledge.
subtasks: Note the availability of the FAO's Agroecology Knowledge Hub for more information on benefits and the 10 elements.
